en-us.learning_promise:
**Learning Promise**
In this unit, your students will apply their engineering design skills to each step of the design process by defining a problem and success criteria, making different prototypes, establishing systematic testing procedures, analyzing data to improve their solutions, and describing why their solution is the best.

lessons.lesson_description: Define a problem by observing a scenario.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Look at the clues. Can you figure out the problem?

text.content:
Sometimes, you only have a few clues to help you figure out a situation.

What are some things you have to do before inventing a solution to a problem?
Kiki has an exciting life but she finds herself in all kinds of weird situations!

comments.comment: This is story #1: Kiki is going for a walk. She’s outside and happy, until...

text.content:
1. Read the story in the comment box
2. Play this program, and start story No.1.
3. Position Kiki in front of each colored brick.

You will hear 3 sounds that will create a story. Listen carefully and let your imagination decide what’s the problem.
An example with the story No.1 could be that Kiki has the problem that she is attached to leash and that she might get hurt because her owner is not paying attention.

1. Play the story No.2.
2. Make a list of all the possible problems Kiki could be having in the story created by these new sounds. 

Meet up with another team and compare your lists.

Change the sounds again. This time you’ll choose your own sounds, so be creative!

Make a list of possible problems Kiki could be having in this new story and have another team do the same.

Compare your lists. Did you make the same predictions?

Think about what you did well and what you could’ve done better.

Congratulations! You’ve taken the first step in becoming an elite member of the Invention Squad.

lessons.title: SPIKE Help

lessons.lesson_description: Design multiple prototypes to find the most effective way to move a robot without using wheels.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Who can make the fastest hopper? Use your skills to prototype legs and get ready to race against other teams!

text.content:
It would be tons of fun to have a hopper race!

How can you improve this walking robot so you’re sure to win the race?

You'll start here. 
You’ll test this one and then modify it to (hopefully) create the fastest hopper!

comments.comment: Adjust this to change the distance your Hopper will move.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Invention-Squad Hopper-Race Step03-Program

text.content: Play the program and watch your hopper move!

Come up with at least 2 new ideas to make your Hopper move even faster.

**Remember:** Anything’s possible, but no wheels!
Here’s some inspiration, but can you think of a better idea?

Place 4 bricks of 2 different colors about **d=50 cm (20 in.)** apart to create a starting line and a finish line.

Place your Hopper at the starting line and play the program.
You might need to adjust the programming block values so your hopper covers the distance between the 2 bricks.

step.title: On your mark, get set, go!

text.content:
Which team built the fastest legs? 

Explain the mechanics of your prototype.

Did you use gears, levers, or pulleys?

Make the race more challenging by adding some loose bricks to the test track. Can your Hopper walk over them and still get to the finish line?

What did you do well? Is there anything you could’ve done better?

Being an inventor also means improving things. Well done!

lessons.title: SPIKE Prime Hopper Race

lessons.lesson_description: Test the efficiency of two different grabber designs and determine the best design based on specific test criteria.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Get your gear ready!  It’s up to you to save the world from litterbugs. Test different grabber designs and help clean up our public spaces.

step.title: Did you see litter on your way to school today ?

text.content:
Wouldn’t it be great to organize a cleanup day? It’s a big job, so you’re gonna need some trash grabbers.

How can you find the best grabber for the job?

You’ll start by testing these 2 grabbers. You’ll also need a controller.

If you have time, you should build and test your own design.

You’ll need :
* 1 LEGO brick
* 1 empty plastic bottle
* 1 ball of crumpled paper  
* 1 stack of LEGO wheels
* 1 apple (or any round fruit)
You can replace the apple by any object of the same size and weight.

step.title: Play this program to test the 2 Grabbers.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Invention-Squad Super-Cleanup Step04-Program

text.content: Which do you think works best?

Try to use each Grabber to pick up the empty bottle, crumpled paper, and LEGO brick.

Give it a score:
* 1 point if it grabs, lifts, and moves the object
* 0 points if it grabs but drops the object
* -1 point if it doesn’t grab or lift the object

Note your scores in a table.

Repeat the last test using  the LEGO wheels, crumpled paper, and an apple 

Note your scores in another table.

* Which Grabber is the best for small objects?
* Which Grabber is the best for heavy objects?

Collect more objects from around your classroom  and predict which Grabber will be best at grabbing and lifting each.

Record a video explaining what you’ve been working on. 

Make sure to include your whole team, even the camera-shy ones!

teacher_support.things_you_will_need:
[LEGO® Education SPIKE™ Prime Set](https://education.lego.com/en-us/products/lego-education-spike-prime-set/45678)
Empty plastic bottle
Ball of crumpled paper
Apple (or object of equivalent weight)

lessons.title: SPIKE Super Cleanup

lessons.lesson_description: Figure out why something isn't working and fix it
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Uh, oh! Your CNC machine is broken and you have to use it as soon as possible.  Quick! Will you be able to fix it? Every good inventor is also able to fix things.

step.title: How quickly can you fix things?

text.content:
Inventing things can also mean fixing things.

What's the first thing you do when something breaks?

step.title: This CNC needs to be fixed.

text.content:
You must troubleshoot and fix your CNC! Start by building the machine:
* CNC Top
* CNC Bottom

step.title: Play This Program to Activate Your CNC

code_stack.title: SPIKE Invention-Squad Broken Step03-Program

text.content:
What goes wrong? 

Describe what you see. Look for the problem.
The CNC is supposed to help you cut parts, but something isn't right.
Don’t change the program. The issues will be found on the CNC itself.

step.title: Have you figured out what’s wrong?

text.content:
* Find out why the CNC isn’t working as it should. 
* Fix the issues.
* Take a picture or video of the issues you’ve found and document your fixes.

Now that your CNC is fixed, make at least 2 improvements. You could:
* Create a reset motor position stack.
* Use the Color Sensor and a black line to create an automatic paper feeder.
* Create a troubleshooting guide. 
* Come up with your own upgrade!

Think about what you did well and how you could improve for next time.

Fixing things makes them last longer. It’s awesome that you can fix stuff!

lessons.title: SPIKE Broken

lessons.lesson_description: Use the complete design process to solve a real-world problem linked to prostheses.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Inventing something for yourself is one thing. But have you ever thought about designing something for someone else?   Let's do something differently. Design your own prosthetic hand and find a new way to open a door, use a toothbrush, eat an apple, or do anything you can imagine!

step.title: Can you design something for someone else?

text.content:
What does it take to design something for another person? 

If you could replace someone's hand with something else, what would it be? What would it do?

step.title: Go crazy, brainstorm, get ideas down on paper!

text.content: Find at least 2 creative ideas for replacing someone's hand with something else.

One idea could be an automatic door opener.

Write down all your ideas in your invention notebook.
Build 2 ”hands” and an arm that does whatever you want.
Visit the building instructions page for inspiration.

Create a different program for each prototype.

Use a fair testing method to compare the prototypes.
Describe what your best prototype is good at (or not so good at) and whether it does what you’d imagined.

What did you do well? Is there something you could’ve done better?

**Congratulations! You’re now an elite member of the Invention Squad!**

lessons.title: SPIKE Design For Someone

en-us.title: SPIKE Invention Squad
en-us.unit_plan_description:
Inventing stuff? Fixing stuff? Always helping people with your ideas? Then you might be an elite member of the Invention Squad!
What will you invent today?
